author: Charles Hodge
text: Christ died for our sins according to the scriptures. This is the gospel in brief: Christ's death was substitutionary (for our sins), scriptural (according to the scriptures), historical (he died), victorious (he rose), and verified (he appeared to witnesses). The resurrection is not a spiritual metaphor but a bodily, historical reality.

author: Matthew Henry
text: O death, where is thy sting? Christ has conquered death. Death once stung with the poison of sin and the curse of the law. But Christ bore that sting in our place. Now death cannot harm believers. It is but a doorway to glory. The grave cannot hold us, for Christ rose victorious, and we shall rise with Him.

author: John Calvin
text: The preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness. The natural man cannot perceive the wisdom of God. To those perishing, the cross appears as foolishness - how can death bring life? But unto us who are saved, it is the power of God. The Spirit opens our eyes to see that in the cross is both the wisdom and power of God for salvation.

author: John Calvin
text: The natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit of God. The unregenerate person cannot understand spiritual truth. It is foolishness to him. He cannot know these things because they are spiritually discerned. Only the Spirit can illuminate the mind to comprehend divine truth. This is why regeneration is absolutely necessary for saving faith.

author: Matthew Henry
text: If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us. Confession is required - acknowledging our sins before God. He is faithful to His promise and just because Christ bore the penalty. He will forgive our sins - remove the guilt. He will cleanse us from all unrighteousness - purify us from sin's pollution. No sin is too great, no stain too deep for His cleansing power.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: Beloved, now are we the sons of God. We are already God's children, though our full glory is not yet revealed. When Christ appears, we shall be like Him - glorified in body and perfected in holiness. We shall see Him as He is - face to face, unveiled, in all His glory. This blessed hope purifies us even now, as we await that glorious day.

author: John Calvin
text: Herein is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us. The source of love is God, not man. We did not first love Him; He first loved us. This love was demonstrated by sending His Son to be the propitiation for our sins. Christ satisfied God's wrath, making atonement for sin. This is love - not sentimental feeling but sacrificial action, God giving His Son to die for His enemies.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. By His abundant mercy, He has begotten us again - regenerated us - to a living hope. This hope is living because it is based on Christ's resurrection. Our inheritance is incorruptible (cannot decay), undefiled (cannot be polluted), and unfading (cannot diminish). It is reserved in heaven, kept by God's power for us.

author: John Calvin
text: Who his own self bare our sins in his own body on the tree. Christ's suffering was substitutionary. He bore our sins - not His own, for He had none. He carried them in His body on the cross, suffering the penalty we deserved. The purpose: that we, being dead to sins, should live unto righteousness. By His stripes we are healed - His wounds brought our healing from sin's guilt and power.

author: Matthew Henry
text: The Lord himself shall descend from heaven. Christ will return personally, visibly, and gloriously. The dead in Christ shall rise first - their bodies reunited with their spirits. Then we who are alive shall be caught up together with them to meet the Lord in the air. And so shall we ever be with the Lord. This is our blessed hope - eternal presence with Christ.

author: John Calvin
text: There is one God, and one mediator between God and men. No priest, no saint, no angel can mediate between God and sinners. There is one mediator - the man Christ Jesus. He is uniquely qualified, being both God and man. He can represent us to God and represent God to us. No other mediator is needed or permitted.

author: Martin Luther
text: He hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin. This is the great exchange. Christ, who had no sin, was made sin for us - bearing our guilt and punishment. That we might be made the righteousness of God in Him - receiving His perfect righteousness. Our sins were imputed to Christ; His righteousness is imputed to us. This is the heart of justification.

author: Matthew Henry
text: His divine power hath given unto us all things. God has given believers everything needed for life and godliness. Not through our power, but through knowledge of Christ who called us. He has given us exceedingly great and precious promises. Through these promises, we become partakers of the divine nature - not in essence, but in character. We escape corruption and are made holy as He is holy.

author: Matthew Henry
text: All scripture is given by inspiration of God. Every part of Scripture is God-breathed - the very words are from God. It is therefore profitable for doctrine (what to believe), reproof (what is wrong), correction (how to get right), and instruction in righteousness (how to stay right). Scripture is sufficient to make the man of God thoroughly furnished unto all good works.

author: John Gill
text: Neither is there salvation in any other. Salvation is not in works, not in rituals, not in any creature, but only in Christ. There is no other name under heaven given among men whereby we must be saved. This name, Jesus, signifies Savior. He alone can save from sin, wrath, and hell. All other refuges are refuges of lies.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Who hath delivered us from the power of darkness. We were under Satan's dominion, in the kingdom of darkness. But God has rescued us and translated us into the kingdom of His dear Son. In whom we have redemption through His blood - deliverance purchased by Christ's atoning sacrifice. Even the forgiveness of sins - complete pardon for all our transgressions.

author: John Calvin
text: Having forgiven you all trespasses. God has blotted out the handwriting of ordinances that was against us - the law that condemned us. He took it away, nailing it to the cross. The law's demands were fully met by Christ. Its curse fell on Him. Its condemnation no longer reaches us. The legal bond is cancelled; we are free.

author: John Calvin
text: Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ. We are blessed with all spiritual blessings in Christ. God chose us in Him before the foundation of the world. Our election is eternal, particular, and in Christ. The purpose was that we should be holy and blameless. Election is unto holiness, not apart from it. All is to the praise of His glorious grace.

author: Matthew Henry
text: In whom we have redemption through his blood. Redemption implies we were in bondage - slaves to sin. Christ's blood is the price that purchased our freedom. This redemption includes the forgiveness of sins. Not just punishment deferred, but sins actually forgiven, removed, blotted out. All according to the riches of His grace - abundant, overflowing, undeserved favor.

author: John Calvin
text: You hath he quickened, who were dead in trespasses and sins. The unregenerate are not merely sick but dead - spiritually lifeless, unable to respond to God. Dead men cannot make themselves alive. Regeneration is resurrection, a sovereign act of God's power. He who raised Christ from the dead must raise our dead souls to spiritual life.

author: Martin Luther
text: For by grace you have been saved through faith. And this is not your own doing; it is the gift of God, not a result of works. This passage demolishes all human merit. Salvation is wholly of grace, faith is the instrument, and even faith itself is God's gift. No room remains for boasting or self-righteousness.

author: Jerome
text: Grace and faith are both gifts of God. We cannot even believe unless God first gives us the ability to believe. The faith by which we are saved is not generated from within ourselves, but is poured into us from heaven. All is of grace, from beginning to end.

author: John Calvin
text: I am crucified with Christ. The believer has died with Christ and risen with Him. The old man is crucified; a new man lives. Nevertheless I live - yet not I, but Christ liveth in me. This is the mystery of the Christian life: we live, yet Christ lives in us. The life we now live is by faith in the Son of God, who loved us and gave Himself for us.

author: Matthew Henry
text: In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth. Observe here, 1. That the world is not eternal. The world had a beginning. 2. That God is eternal, and has no beginning. Before all worlds, God was. 3. That God made all things out of nothing by the word of his power. There was not any pre-existent matter out of which the world was produced. 4. That the heaven and the earth include the whole universe, all beings besides God. The Creator is eternal, the creature had a beginning.

author: Basil the Great
source: Hexaemeron (On the Six Days of Creation)
text: In the beginning God created. What a sublime and magnificent beginning! He does not tell us when this beginning was, but simply that there was a beginning. Time had not yet come into existence. The beginning of time was the creation of the heavens and the earth. Before this, there was God alone, existing in eternity. The words 'In the beginning' take us beyond all conception of time to the eternal counsel of God.

author: Athanasius
text: The Son is the brightness of God's glory and the express image of His person. The Son is the radiance of divine glory - co-eternal, co-equal, of the same essence as the Father. He is the exact representation of God's nature. He upholds all things by His powerful word. Having purged our sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high, His atoning work complete.

author: John Calvin
text: The word of God is quick and powerful. Scripture is not dead letter but living and active. It is sharper than any two-edged sword, penetrating to the deepest recesses of the human heart. It divides soul and spirit, discerning thoughts and intentions. No creature is hidden from God's word - it exposes all, judges all, reveals all.

author: Matthew Henry
text: He is able to save them to the uttermost. Christ's saving power is complete and perpetual. He saves to the uttermost - to the fullest extent, forever. He saves all who come to God through Him - there are no exceptions among those who truly come. He ever liveth to make intercession - His priestly work continues. Because He lives forever, His priesthood is unchangeable and His salvation eternal.

author: John Calvin
text: It is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment. Death is appointed - certain for all. Once to die - there is no reincarnation, no second chance. After death comes judgment - not annihilation, not soul sleep, but immediate facing of God's tribunal. This should drive us to seek Christ now, for after death it will be too late.

author: John Owen
text: By one offering he hath perfected for ever them that are sanctified. Christ's sacrifice was once for all - never to be repeated. By this one offering, He has perfected forever - completely and eternally - those who are being sanctified. Our justification is complete; our sanctification is progressive. But both rest on Christ's finished work.

author: John Chrysostom
text: Faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen. Faith gives substance to what we hope for. It makes future blessings present to the soul. It is the eye of the soul by which we see invisible realities. Without faith, the promises of God seem empty; with faith, they become more real than the things we touch.

author: John Owen
text: Faith is that grace whereby we are enabled to believe all that God has revealed in His word. It gives subsistence to things hoped for - making them real to the soul even before they are possessed. It evidences things not seen - providing conviction about invisible spiritual realities. Faith rests wholly on the testimony and promise of God.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith. Keep your eyes fixed on Christ. He is the author - He began the work of faith in us. He is the finisher - He will complete it. For the joy set before Him, He endured the cross, despising the shame. If Christ endured such suffering for us, we can endure lesser trials for Him. He now sits at God's right hand, His work complete, His victory won.

author: John Calvin
text: But he was wounded for our transgressions. This is the heart of the gospel. Christ bore not His own sins but ours. The punishment that brought us peace was upon Him. By His stripes - the wounds inflicted upon Him - we are healed. This healing is not primarily physical but spiritual: the healing of our souls from the disease of sin.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: All we like sheep have gone astray. Here is the universality of sin - all have gone astray. Here is the individuality of sin - each has turned to his own way. Here is the remedy - the LORD has laid on Him the iniquity of us all. Christ bore the sins of all His people. God's justice fell upon the Substitute, that mercy might flow to the guilty.

author: John Calvin
text: Faith without works is dead. True saving faith always produces good works. Not that works save us - we are justified by faith alone. But the faith that justifies is never alone - it is always accompanied by works. Dead faith is mere intellectual assent without heart transformation. Living faith produces obedience. Works are not the root of salvation, but they are the fruit.

author: Athanasius
text: In the beginning was the Word. The Word was not made, but always was. The Word is eternal, co-equal, and co-eternal with the Father. This passage demolishes the Arian heresy which claims the Son was created. The Word is God Himself, the second person of the Trinity. He who is the Word became flesh, but He never ceased to be the eternal Word.

author: John Calvin
text: In the beginning was the Word. The Evangelist opens with the divinity of Christ. The Word was in the beginning, which means He is eternal. The Word was with God - distinct in person yet one in essence. The Word was God - possessing the same divine nature. These three declarations establish both the deity and the personal distinction of the Son.

author: Athanasius
text: The Word was made flesh. The eternal Son took to Himself a human nature. He did not cease to be God, but became man. Two natures united in one person. He dwelt among us - literally 'tabernacled' with us. As God's glory filled the tabernacle of old, so divine glory dwelt in the human nature of Christ. We beheld His glory, full of grace and truth.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Behold the Lamb of God. John points away from himself to Christ. The Lamb of God is the antitype of all Old Testament sacrifices. He is the true Passover Lamb. He takes away sin - not by covering it, but by removing it entirely. He takes away the sin of the world - His sacrifice is sufficient for all, though effectual only for the elect who believe.

author: John Calvin
text: Ye must be born again. Regeneration is absolutely necessary. No one can see or enter the kingdom of God without it. This new birth is not physical but spiritual, not natural but supernatural. It is not an improvement of the old nature but the creation of a new nature. Man cannot regenerate himself; this is the work of the Holy Spirit alone.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: God so loved the world - not a select few, not merely the nation of Israel, but the world. Yet this love is effectual only in those who believe. The gift of the Son is universal in its offer, but particular in its application. Whosoever believes shall not perish, and this belief is itself a gift of grace.

author: John Chrysostom
text: See how the Son is given. Not by compulsion, not by necessity, but willingly. The Father gave Him, and the Son gave Himself. This is the wonder of God's love - that He should give His own Son for those who were His enemies. And what is required? Only faith, only to believe on Him.

author: John Calvin
text: All that the Father giveth me shall come to me. Here is the doctrine of effectual calling. Those whom the Father has chosen and given to the Son will infallibly come to Christ. Their coming is certain because it is the result of the Father's gift and the Spirit's work. And him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out - here is the security of believers.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Before Abraham was, I am. Christ claims eternal existence and applies to Himself the divine name I AM - the very name God revealed to Moses at the burning bush. This is an unmistakable claim to deity. The Jews understood this claim, which is why they took up stones to execute Him for blasphemy. But it was no blasphemy, for Christ is truly God.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: I am the good shepherd. Christ is not merely a shepherd, but the good shepherd. He knows His sheep, they know Him, and He lays down His life for them. The hireling flees when danger comes, but the good shepherd dies for the sheep. Christ's death was voluntary, substitutionary, and effectual for all His flock.

author: John Calvin
text: I am the resurrection and the life. Christ does not merely give resurrection and life - He is resurrection and life. Life is found in Him alone. Those who believe in Him, though they die physically, shall live eternally. And those who live and believe in Him shall never die spiritually. Death has lost its sting for believers because Christ has conquered death.

author: Matthew Henry
text: I am the way, the truth, and the life. Christ is THE way, not merely A way. He is the true and living way to the Father. He is the truth - the substance of all Old Testament types, the fulfillment of all prophecies. He is the life - the source of all spiritual and eternal life. No man cometh unto the Father but by me - this excludes all other ways of salvation.

author: John Calvin
text: Without me ye can do nothing. Apart from Christ, we have no spiritual strength, no ability to please God, no power to bear fruit. We are utterly dependent upon Him. But abiding in Him, we bear much fruit. The branch derives all its life and fruitfulness from the vine. So we derive all spiritual life and power from Christ through the Spirit.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: Blessed are the poor in spirit. This is voluntary poverty of spirit - recognizing our spiritual bankruptcy before God. We are blessed not by possessing spiritual riches of our own, but by acknowledging that we have none. The kingdom of heaven belongs to those who renounce all confidence in their own righteousness and cast themselves wholly on God's mercy.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Blessed are the poor in spirit. Those are poor in spirit who are humble and lowly in their own eyes, who see their own spiritual poverty and need. They are empty of self-righteousness, empty of self-sufficiency, and therefore capable of being filled with the riches of God's grace. Theirs is the kingdom of heaven, both in present possession and future perfection.

author: John Calvin
text: Blessed are the pure in heart. Purity of heart is more than outward morality. It is internal holiness, freedom from the pollution of sin in thought and desire. The pure in heart shall see God - not in this life with bodily eyes, but in the life to come they shall behold Him face to face. Even now, they see Him by faith, beholding His glory in Christ.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Seek ye first the kingdom of God. The kingdom of God must have the first place in our hearts and lives. His righteousness must be our primary pursuit. When God has the supremacy, all other things - food, clothing, temporal needs - shall be added unto us. God will provide for those who make Him their priority. Anxiety about earthly things reveals misplaced priorities.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden. What a gracious invitation! Christ calls the weary, the burdened, the heavy laden. He does not say 'Work for rest' but 'Come and I will give you rest.' Rest is His gift, not our achievement. The rest He gives is rest of conscience, rest from the burden of sin and guilt, rest in the finished work of Christ.

author: John Calvin
text: Thou art the Christ, the Son of the living God. Peter's confession is the foundation of the church. Christ is the Messiah promised in the Old Testament. He is the Son of God - not by adoption but by nature, sharing the divine essence. This confession was not the product of Peter's wisdom but of divine revelation. The Father must open our eyes to see Christ's true identity.

author: Matthew Henry
text: All power is given unto me. Christ possesses all authority in heaven and earth. Based on this authority, He commissions His church to make disciples of all nations. The Great Commission rests on the Great Authority. We go in His power, baptizing in the name of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, teaching all that Christ commanded. This Trinitarian formula establishes the doctrine of the Trinity.

author: Matthew Henry
text: He which hath begun a good work in you will perform it. God finishes what He begins. He who started the work of grace will complete it. This is the doctrine of perseverance - not our perseverance in ourselves, but God's perseverance in saving us. He will continue His sanctifying work until the day of Jesus Christ, when we shall be fully conformed to Christ's image.

author: Athanasius
text: Christ Jesus, being in the form of God, thought it not robbery to be equal with God. Christ possessed equality with God from all eternity. He did not grasp at equality as something to be attained, for He already possessed it. Yet He emptied Himself, taking the form of a servant. The divine nature remained; He took human nature in addition to it. Truly God became truly man.

author: John Chrysostom
text: Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling, for it is God who works in you. We must work, yet it is God who works in us both to will and to do. Our working and God's working are not opposed but united. We work because God works in us. The fear and trembling arise from recognizing the greatness of the work and our utter dependence on divine grace.

author: John Calvin
text: Not having mine own righteousness. Paul renounces all self-righteousness. He desires to be found in Christ, having not his own righteousness which is of the law, but the righteousness which is through faith in Christ. Our righteousness is alien - it is Christ's righteousness imputed to us. We are accepted in the Beloved, clothed with His perfect obedience.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: Blessed is the man. See how the psalmist begins with blessedness! This is the mark of the godly - they are blessed. The ungodly may prosper for a season, but they are not blessed. True happiness is found not in the counsel of the wicked, but in the law of the Lord. The blessed man avoids evil company, evil ways, and evil attitudes.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: His delight is in the law of the LORD. The blessed man not only reads God's law but delights in it. He meditates upon it day and night. This meditation is not a burden but a joy. The word of God becomes sweeter than honey to his taste. By constant meditation, the law is written upon his heart and becomes the guide of all his actions.

author: Matthew Henry
text: What is man, that thou art mindful of him? When we consider the vastness of God's creation, we must wonder at His condescension in caring for such insignificant creatures as we are. Yet God has crowned man with glory and honor, making him but little lower than the angels. This psalm ultimately points to Christ, who became man to redeem man.

author: John Calvin
text: The heavens declare the glory of God. The whole fabric of the universe is a mirror in which we may behold God. The heavens are a preacher, proclaiming without words the wisdom, power, and goodness of the Creator. No man can plead ignorance of God, for creation itself is a clear testimony to His existence and attributes.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: My God, my God, why hast thou forsaken me? These are the words our Savior uttered upon the cross. David spoke prophetically of Christ's sufferings. In His darkest hour, Christ was forsaken by God that we might never be forsaken. He bore the full weight of divine wrath against sin, experiencing separation from the Father so that we might enjoy eternal fellowship with God.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: The LORD is my shepherd. Here is a personal interest - 'my shepherd'; a present tense - 'is'; and a delightful object - 'the LORD.' David had been a shepherd himself, and he could therefore appreciate the care which the Great Shepherd bestows upon His flock. No title can be more rich in consolation than this which the living God assumes - 'The LORD is my shepherd.' It is a covenant title, implying a relationship which nothing can dissolve.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: The Lord feedeth me, and I shall lack nothing. He who hath Christ for his Shepherd needs nothing. Christ is the true Shepherd who gave His life for the sheep. He pastures us in the field of the Scriptures. In the verdant pastures of His word, there is abundance of spiritual nourishment. Under His care, we have all things necessary for life and godliness.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven. This is the blessedness of justification. Sin is described three ways: transgression (rebellion against God's law), sin (missing the mark), and iniquity (moral perversity). Forgiveness is described two ways: sin is forgiven (the debt is cancelled) and covered (hidden from God's sight). This blessing comes not through our works but through faith in Christ's atonement.

author: John Calvin
text: Behold, I was shapen in iniquity. David here confesses the doctrine of original sin. We are not sinners merely because we commit sinful acts; we commit sinful acts because we are sinners by nature. From our conception, we bear the corruption of Adam's fall. This humbling truth drives us to seek grace, for if we are sinful from birth, we cannot save ourselves.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: Create in me a clean heart, O God. David asks for creation, not mere reformation. Only God can create; only He can make the heart clean. We cannot purify ourselves. The renewal of the spirit is a divine work. God must create what is new in us, for our own hearts are desperately wicked and beyond our power to cleanse.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: Bless the LORD, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits. Memory is treacherous when it comes to blessings. We easily remember our trials but forget our mercies. God forgives all our iniquities - not some, but all. He heals all our diseases - both spiritual and physical maladies. Let us recount His benefits lest ingratitude should rob us of joy and God of glory.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Thy word have I hid in mine heart. The word must not merely be read with the eyes or heard with the ears, but hidden in the heart. This means memorizing it, meditating upon it, and treasuring it. The purpose is practical: that I might not sin against thee. The word hidden in the heart is the best preservative against sin. It sanctifies, directs, and restrains.

author: Augustine of Hippo
text: Whither shall I go from thy spirit? God is omnipresent. There is no place where He is not. If I ascend to heaven, He is there. If I make my bed in hell, He is there also. This is terror to the wicked but comfort to the godly. The believer cannot flee from God's presence, nor would he wish to, for God's presence is his joy and security.

author: Victorinus
text: I am Alpha and Omega, the beginning and the ending. Christ is the first and the last, the beginning and the end. All things are from Him and all things are unto Him. He is before all things and after all things. He spans all time and eternity. This title declares His absolute sovereignty and His eternal deity.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Fear not; I am the first and the last. Christ comforts John with the revelation of His eternal nature and His victory over death. I am he that liveth and was dead - He truly died. And behold, I am alive for evermore - He conquered death and lives eternally. He has the keys of hell and of death - absolute authority over the grave. Death cannot hold believers because Christ defeated it.

author: Matthew Henry
text: Thou art worthy to take the book. Only the Lamb who was slain is worthy to open the seals and reveal God's purposes. Thou wast slain and hast redeemed us to God by thy blood. Redemption was purchased by Christ's blood. Out of every kindred and tongue and people and nation - the elect are gathered from all humanity. Christ's death has secured a multitude that no man can number from every tribe and language.

author: Matthew Henry
text: God shall wipe away all tears from their eyes. In the new heaven and new earth, there will be no more sorrow. Death shall be no more - it is the last enemy to be destroyed. Neither sorrow, nor crying, nor pain - all effects of the curse removed. Former things are passed away - the old order of suffering and sin is gone forever. This is our hope: eternal joy in God's presence.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: Whosoever will, let him take the water of life freely. This is the gospel's final invitation. The Spirit and the bride say, Come. Let him that heareth say, Come. Let him that is athirst come. And whosoever will, let him take freely. Salvation is offered to all without money and without price. Let all who thirst for righteousness come to Christ and drink. The invitation is universal; the gift is free.

author: John Calvin
text: 1. Paul, etc.  - With regard to the word Paul, as it is a subject of no such moment as ought to detain us, and as nothing can be said which has not been mentioned by other expounders, I should say nothing, were it not proper to satisfy some at small expense without being tedious to others; for the subject shall be despatched in a very few words. They who think that the Apostle attained this name as a trophy for having brought Sergius, the proconsul, to the faith of Christ, are confuted by the testimony of Luke, who shows that he was so called before that time. author: John Calvin
text: I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ. Paul glories in what the world despises. The gospel appears weak and foolish to human wisdom, yet it is the power of God unto salvation. This power operates through the preaching of the cross. It is effectual for everyone who believes - first the Jew, then the Gentile. Faith is the instrument by which this saving power is received.

author: Martin Luther
text: The just shall live by faith. This text was the key that opened paradise to me. I saw that the righteousness of God is not that by which He is righteous in Himself, but that which He freely gives to sinners through faith in Christ. The righteous person is he who believes the gospel, and such a one shall live - eternally - by this faith alone.

author: John Calvin
text: 16. For  the righteousness of God, etc. This is an explanation and a confirmation of the preceding clause - that the gospel is the power of God unto salvation.

author: Charles Hodge

This willful rejection brings divine judgment.

author: John Calvin
text: There is none righteous, no, not one. This is Paul's verdict on all humanity. Righteousness is completely absent from fallen human nature. Not one person, by nature, seeks after God or does good. All have turned aside and become worthless. This universal condemnation drives us to seek righteousness outside ourselves - in Christ alone.

author: John Calvin

text: 27. Where then is glorying? The Apostle, after having, with reasons abundantly strong, cast down men from their confidence in works, now triumphs over their folly: and this exulting conclusion was necessary; for on this subject, to teach us would not have been enough; it was necessary that the Holy Spirit should loudly thunder, in order to lay prostrate our loftiness. Justification by faith is indeed made very clear, while works are expressly excluded.

text: 4. To him indeed who works, etc. It is not he, whom he calls a worker, who is given to good works, to which all the children of God ought to attend, but the person who seeks to merit something by his works: and in a similar way he calls him no worker who depends not on the merit of what he does. He would not, indeed, have the faithful to be idle; but he only forbids them to be mercenaries, so as to demand any thing from God, as though it were justly their due. 5 . But believes on him, etc. This is a very important sentence, in which he expresses the substance and nature both of faith and of righteousness. He indeed clearly shews that faith brings us righteousness, not because it is a meritorious act, but because it obtains for us the favor of God.

author: John Calvin
text: To him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly. This is the wonder of justification - God justifies the ungodly, not the godly. He accepts those who have no righteousness of their own but trust in Christ. Faith is not a work; it is the cessation of works. It is resting in what Christ has accomplished rather than attempting to earn salvation ourselves.

text: Being justified by faith, we have peace with God. Justification brings peace. The war between the sinner and God is ended. We have peace - present possession, not future hope. author: John Calvin
text: 19. I speak what is human , etc. He says that he speaks after the manner of men, not as to the substance but as to the manner. So Christ says, in John 3:12 , that he announced earthly things, while yet he spoke of heavenly mysteries, though not so magnificently as the dignity of the things required, because he accommodated himself to the capacities of a people ignorant and simple. And thus the Apostle says, by way of preface, that he might more fully show how gross and wicked is the calumny, when it is imagined, that the freedom obtained by Christ gives liberty to sin.

author: John Calvin
text: 20. For when ye were, etc. He still repeats the difference, which he had before mentioned, between the yoke of righteousness and that of sin; for these two things, sin and righteousness, are so contrary, that he who devotes himself to the one, necessarily departs from the other. And he thus represents both, that by viewing them apart we may see more clearly what is to be expected from each; for to set things thus apart enables us to understand better their distinctive character. 21. What fruit, then , etc. He could not more strikingly express what he intended than by appealing to their conscience, and by confessing shame as it were in their person.

author: Charles Spurgeon
text: The wages of sin is death. Sin pays wages - death is what we have earned. But the gift of God is eternal life. Wages are earned; gifts are freely given. We earned death by our sin, but eternal life cannot be earned - it is God's free gift. This life is in Christ Jesus our Lord, and nowhere else. In Him is life; apart from Him is only death.

author: John Calvin
text: 13. Has then what is good , etc. He had hitherto defended the law from calumnies, but in such a manner, that it still remained doubtful whether it was the cause of death; nay, the minds of men were on this point perplexed, - how could it be that nothing but death was gained from so singular a gift of God. To this objection then he now gives an answer; and he denies, that death proceeds from the law, though death through its means is brought on us by sin.

author: John Calvin
text: 14. For we know that the law, etc. He now begins more closely to compare the law with what man is, that it may be more clearly understood whence the evil of death proceeds. He then sets before us an example in a regenerate man, in whom the remnants of the flesh are wholly contrary to the law of the Lord, while the spirit would gladly obey it. But first, as we have said, he makes only a comparison between nature and the law. 15. For what I do I know not , etc. He now comes to a more particular case, that of a man already regenerated;  in whom both the things which he had in view appear more clearly; and these were, - the great discord there is between the Law of God and the natural man, - and how the law does not of itself produce death.

author: John Calvin
text: 24. Miserable , etc. He closes his argument with a vehement exclamation, by which he teaches us that we are not only to struggle with our flesh, but also with continual groaning to bewail within ourselves and before God our unhappy condition. But he asks not by whom he was to be delivered, as one in doubt, like unbelievers, who understand not that there is but one real deliverer: but it is the voice of one panting and almost fainting, because he does not find immediate help,  as he longs for. 25. I thank God; etc. He then immediately subjoined this thanksgiving, lest any should think that in his complaint he perversely murmured against God; for we know how easy even in legitimate grief is the transition to discontent and impatience.

author: John Calvin
text: There is therefore now no condemnation. This is the believer's triumph. No condemnation - not now, not ever, not in any degree. We were under condemnation, justly sentenced to death. But now, united to Christ Jesus, we are free. The law's demands have been met by Christ. God's wrath has been satisfied. No charge can stand against God's elect.

text: For whom he did foreknow, he also did predestinate. author: John Calvin
text: 29. For whom he has foreknown, etc. He then shows, by the very order of election, that the afflictions of the faithful are nothing else than the manner by which they are conformed to the image of Christ; and that this was necessary, he had before declared. There is therefore no reason for us to be grieved, or to think it hard and grievous, that we are afflicted, unless we disapprove of the Lord's election, by which we have been foreordained to life, and unless we are unwilling to bear the image of the Son of God, by which we are to be prepared for celestial glory. But the foreknowledge of God, which Paul mentions, is not a bare prescience, as some unwise persons absurdly imagine, but the adoption by which he had always distinguished his children from the reprobate. In the same sense Peter says, that the faithful had been elected to the sanctification of the Spirit according to the foreknowledge of God. Hence those, to whom I have alluded, foolishly draw this inference — that God has elected none but those whom he foresaw would be worthy of his grace. Peter does not indeed flatter the faithful, as though every one had been elected on account of his merit; but by reminding them of the eternal counsel of God, he wholly deprives them of all worthiness. So Paul does in this passage, who repeats by another word what he had said before of God's purpose. It hence follows, that this knowledge is connected with God's good pleasure; for he foreknew nothing out of himself, in adopting those whom he was pleased to adopt; but only marked out those whom he had purposed to elect. The verb 'to predestinate' is to be understood according to what this passage requires; for Paul only meant, that God had so determined that all whom he has adopted should bear the image of Christ; nor has he simply said, that they were to be conformed to Christ, but to the image of Christ, that he might teach us that there is in Christ a living and conspicuous exemplar, which is exhibited to God's children for imitation. The meaning then is, that gratuitous adoption, in which our salvation consists, is inseparable from the other decree, which determines that we are to bear the cross; for no one can be an heir of heaven without being conformed to the image of the only-begotten Son of God. That he may be the first-born, etc. In mentioning Christ's primogeniture, Paul meant only to express this — that since Christ possesses a pre-eminence among the children of God, he is rightly given to us as a pattern, so that we ought to refuse nothing which he has been pleased to undergo. Hence, that the celestial Father may in every way bear testimony to the authority and honor which he has conferred on his own Son, he will have all those whom he adopts to be the heirs of his kingdom, to be conformed to his example.

author: John Calvin
text: In this chapter he begins to remove the offences which might have diverted the minds of men from Christ: for the Jews, for whom he was appointed according to the covenant of the law, not only rejected him, but regarded him with contempt, and for the most part hated him. Hence one of two things seemed to follow, - either that there was no truth in the Divine promise, - or that Jesus, whom Paul preached, was not the Lord’s anointed, who had been especially promised to the Jews. This twofold knot Paul fully unties in what follows. 2. That I have great sorrow, etc. He dexterously manages so to cut short his sentence as not yet to express what he was going to say; for it was not as yet seasonable openly to mention the destruction of the Jewish nation.

author: John Calvin
text: 22. See then, etc. By laying the case before their eyes he more clearly and fully confirms the fact, - that the Gentiles had no reason to be proud. They saw in the Jews an example of God’s severity, which ought to have terrified them; while in themselves they had an evidence of his grace and goodness, by which they ought to have been stimulated to thankfulness only, and to exalt the Lord and not themselves. 23. For God is able, etc . Frigid would this argument be to the profane; for however they may concede power to God, yet as they view it at a distance, shut up as it were in heaven, they do for the most part rob it of its effect. But as the faithful, whenever they hear God’s power named, look on it as in present operation, he thought that this reason was sufficient to strike their minds.

text: Present your bodies a living sacrifice. In view of God's mercies - all the blessings unfolded in chapters 1-11 - we are exhorted to total consecration. This is our reasonable service - our logical and spiritual worship in response to redeeming grace.

text: 4. text: 9. Let love be, etc. Proceeding now to speak of particular duties, he fitly begins with love, which is the bond of perfection. And respecting this he enjoins what is especially necessary, that all disguises are to be cast aside, and that love is to arise from pure sincerity of mind. text: 1. Let every soul,  etc. Inasmuch as he so carefully handles this subject in connection with what forms the Christian life, it appears that he was constrained to do so by some great necessity which existed especially in that age, though the preaching of the gospel at all times renders this necessary. There are indeed always some tumultuous spirits who believe that the kingdom of Christ cannot be sufficiently elevated, unless all earthly powers be abolished, and that they cannot enjoy the liberty given by him, except they shake off every yoke of human subjection. 2. And they who resist, etc. As no one can resist God but to his own ruin, he threatens, that they shall not be unpunished who in this respect oppose the providence of God. Let us then beware, lest we incur this denunciation.

But thou, why dost thou, etc. As he had made the life and death of us all subject to Christ, he now proceeds to mention the authority to judge, which the Father has conferred on him, together with the dominion over heaven and earth. text: 22. Hast thou faith? In order to conclude, he shows in what consists the advantage of Christian liberty: it hence appears, that they boast falsely of liberty who know not how to make a right use of it. He then says, that liberty really understood, as it is that of faith, has properly a regard to God; so that he who is endued with a conviction of this kind, ought to be satisfied with peace of conscience before God; nor is it needful for him to show before men that he possesses it. 23. But he who is undecided, etc. He very fitly expresses in one word the character of that mind which vacillates and is uncertain as to what ought to be done; for he who is undecided undergoes alternate changes, and in the midst of his various deliberations is held suspended by uncertainty.

I have then, etc. After having in general commended his own calling, that the Romans might know that he was a true and undoubted apostle of Christ, he now adds testimonies, by which he proved that he had not only taken upon him the apostolic office conferred on him by God’s appointment, but that he had also eminently adorned it. Now I beseech you, etc. It is well known from many passages how much ill-will prevailed against Paul in his own nation on account of false reports, as though he taught a departure from Moses. And I beseech you, etc. He now adds an exhortation, by which all Churches have often need of being stirred up; for the ministers of Satan are ever ready to take occasion to disturb the kingdom of Christ: and they attempt to make disturbances in two ways; for they either sow discord, by which the minds of men are drawn away from the unity of truth, or they occasion offenses, by which men are alienated from the love of the gospel. 18. For they who are such, etc. He mentions an unvarying mark, by which false prophets are to be distinguished from the servants of Christ; for they have no care for the glory of Christ, but seek the benefit of their stomach.

author: John Calvin
text: 21. Timothy, etc. The salutations which he records, served in part to foster union between those who were far asunder, and in part to make the Romans know that their brethren subscribed to the Epistle; not that Paul had need of the testimony of others, but because the consent of the godly is not of small importance. The Epistle closes, as we see, with praise and thanksgiving to God. It indeed records the remarkable kindness of God in favoring the Gentiles with the light of the gospel, by which his infinite and unspeakable goodness has been made evident.
